Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Proposal: Rheology and Flow of Geometrically Cohesive Granular Materials

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

PI: Teitel

This project investigates a class of granular materials that are geometrically cohesive, e.g. a collective pile of particles that resists tensile forces. Examples of geometrically cohesive granular materials (GCGM) include long, thin rods (e.g. haystacks) and concave-shaped particles (semi-circles or U-shaped staples). These materials present a rich opportunity for basic research as well as new practical applications where structural rigidity, lightweight, and porosity are desired.

Computer simulations and experiments for a variety of particle shapes - rods, semi-circles, and U-shaped staples - will be carried out to provide a better micro and macroscopic understanding of how particle shape affects fluidization and solidification in GCGM. Experiments previously carried out to characterize spherical granular media?basic rheology, tumbling, collapse, and flow ? will be repeated for the above complex-shaped particles. Numerical simulations using the Discrete Element Method will be used to probe the particle-level mechanism by which geometric cohesion occurs. New parallelization techniques involving graphics processing units (GPUs) will be developed for simulating thousands of particles. These experimental and computational studies will be used to explore the possible universality in geometric cohesion, the scaling of critical lengths, and the fundamental mechanism by which this cohesion occurs.

This work will lead to increased understanding of granular materials consisting of complex shaped particles, a common occurrence in many industrial processes. The project also initiates collaboration between two institutions: a primarily undergraduate institute, Rochester Institute of Technology, and an R1 research university, University of Rochester. The collaboration will engage undergraduate and graduate students in a rich educational experience that emphasizes communication between experimentalists and computational researchers. Simulations and table-top experiments will allow undergraduates to engage in cutting edge research at both institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Geometrically cohesive granular materials are systems that show significant entanglement, and therefore cohesiveness, due solely to individual particle shape. Examples include long, thin sticks (a haystack, for example) or clumps of U-shaped staples. The mechanical stability that these materials show gives rise to both intriguing industrial applications (e.g. construction) and also problems, most notably in the flow of pharmaceutical powders or coastal sands. In this project, we studied the ability of these materials to resist extensional and shear forces.

A major finding was that the resistance of these piles obeys a "weakest link" like behavior in which the total strength is dependent on the weakest part within. There are a number of consequences, the most obvious being that larger collections, because they have a higher chance of containing a weak link, are in fact significantly weaker than short piles (see Figure). 

Another finding is that these piles almost completely "self-heal." When a pile of staples is pulled apart, the pile resists until the weakest part slips, and the pile grows a bit in response. But the particles inevitably re-entangle, and the pile stops growing and again becomes rigid. This new entanglement is virtually indistnguishable (in strength) from the pre-slip configuration, and so each pile can be thought of as "new," independent of its history. Because of this, many of the pile's behaviors can be explained by a single function of only two variables: the applied force and the pile's instantaneous length. With this theoretical explanation, extensional experiments reduce to measuring a single critical scaling exponent that connects the average failure force with the instaneous length. We find this exponent to be approximately 1, and as a result can collapse all data (all forces all lengths) onto a single curve (see Figure).

In addition to experiments, we wrote new computer simulations to model these and related systems. These simulations investigated pure shear conditions and confirmed the tendency of long rod-like particles to align and the details of how more complicated geometries entangle. This last characteristic has a surprising biological application related to the collected behavior of communal insects (e.g. fire ants). Ants often come together to form an entangled mass or raft which they use to span gaps (as a bridge) or float a river (a critical component of their unfortunate spread northward). Collaborators at Georgia Tech have conducted experiments in which antpiles are pulled apart, and the corresponding force and pile geometry measured. By recognizing that staples and cohesive granular materials can be seen as an analogous model for ants, we modified our program to account for activity and the ants' tendency to hold on tighter when stretched. We are now able to reproduce qualitative behaviors of these piles, in particular the observation that larger piles are not proportionally stronger than smaller piles. That is, doubling the number of ants results in a pile that, while stronger, is not twice as strong. This is now seen to result from simple statistics and does not reflect a change in behavior of individual ants.
